dt: {bc}an inexpensive lodging facility for usually young travelers that typically has dormitory-style sleeping arrangements and sometimes offers meals and planned activities
{bc}a supervised institutional residence or shelter (as for homeless people)

et: Middle English, "lodging, accommodation, inn, dwelling place," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}ostel, hostel,{/it} going back to Latin {it}hospitāle{/it} "guest accommodation" (in plural {it}hospitālia{/it}) {ma}{mat|hospital|}{/ma}

Latin {it}hospitāle{/it} as a noun is very sparsely attested in texts before the later Middle Ages, though the phonetic development to {it}ostel{/it} and its semantic diversification show that it must have been well-established in Gallo-Romance at an early date.
shortdef: an inexpensive lodging facility for usually young travelers that typically has dormitory-style sleeping arrangements and sometimes offers meals and planned activities —called also youth hostel
a supervised institutional residence or shelter (as for homeless people)

dt: {bc}to stay at {a_link|hostels} overnight in the course of traveling

shortdef: to stay at hostels overnight in the course of traveling
